title: Will Ukrainian energy become a magnet for EU green investments? - ceenergynews
description:
In the European energy sector, 2022–2025 became a period of rethinking.
Just yesterday, the world was trying to find a balance between cheap gas, the growth of green energy, and the logic of the electricity market.
The World and the EU in 2022-2025: New Rules, New Networks, New Consumers The European Union responded to the energy shock with packages of new rules and investments.
Investors should make decisions about this, and the regulatory background is already clear, thanks to European rules and Ukrainian policies in the field of hydrogen energy.
We need our own accelerated grid reconstruction plan with a priority for the rapid connection of new generation and storage facilities, like the Energy Infrastructure Plan for Europe.
text:
Op-ed by Oleksiy Hnatenko, Partner at Juscutum.

In the European energy sector, 2022–2025 became a period of rethinking. Just yesterday, the world was trying to find a balance between cheap gas, the growth of green energy, and the logic of the electricity market. But today, Europe is already building new networks, introducing digital rules for trade transparency, and preparing space for industries that are sharply increasing demand for electricity, starting with data centres and ending with electric transport.

During this same time, Ukraine has lived several “energy lives”. It lost energy infrastructure facilities after missile strikes and simultaneously synchronised with the European network, put into operation the largest energy storage systems in the region, and reshaped the investment optics of business. It is painful, but productive: the war forced us to move from the “theory of transition” to the “practice of sustainability”.

The World and the EU in 2022-2025: New Rules, New Networks, New Consumers

The European Union responded to the energy shock with packages of new rules and investments. The electricity market reform consolidated stable long-term instruments and reduced the impact of gas price fluctuations on the price of electricity. In parallel, the modernisation of energy trade supervision increased transparency and responsibility of players. At the infrastructure level, a plan for the rapid completion of networks and interstate connections appeared. And, finally, a new major consumer entered the European agenda – artificial intelligence with its data centres, which in a few years will add dozens of terawatt-hours of demand and force the acceleration of investments in networks, flexibility and demand management.

A separate trend for 2022-2025 is the return of hydrogen from the plane of slogans to the plane of rules and investments. The EU has launched the European Hydrogen Bank with production support auctions, defined green criteria for electrolyser hydrogen (RFNBO) and low-carbon hydrogen, and enabled the phased development of hydrogen infrastructure within the framework of projects of common interest. This loop is connected to transport: at sea, requirements to reduce the carbon intensity of fuel on ships have come into force, in aviation, minimum shares of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), opening the door to e-methanol and “green” ammonia as energy carriers in these areas.

Europe’s hydrogen ambitions are no longer an abstraction. In 2025, the world’s first commercial e-methanol plant, powered by renewable electricity and captured CO₂, opened in Denmark. The maritime industry has also accelerated contracts for the new fuel. This does not yet solve all the cost problems, but it is already shaping a market with forecasted demand.

Ukraine in 2025: Networks, Imports and Internal Flexibility

After emergency synchronisation with the European network in March 2022, Ukraine not only kept its power system operational, but also opened commercial trade. For the autumn-winter period of 2024-2025, European operators increased the limit on electricity imports to Ukraine to 2.1 gigawatts (GW). This volume was agreed not within the framework of a preferential regime, but determined by the technical capabilities of the system, which has been tested by war and, in this regime, fulfils the conditions of a stabilisation nature.

Ukraine’s response to the electricity shortage and the destruction and decommissioning of energy infrastructure due to Russian shelling was the need to create internal flexibility. In 2025, private investors introduced a portfolio of energy storage systems with a total capacity of 200 megawatts and a capacity of 400 MWh. These are six sites optimised for balancing and emergency modes, which are already undergoing commercial testing and will operate under contracts with the transmission system operator. To put it simply, two hours of reserve for hundreds of thousands of households, exactly when it is needed most.

This did not arise in a vacuum. Back in 2023–2024, the business was massively diversifying towards gas-piston plants and small-scale cogeneration. Cities were buying mini-CHPs based on Jenbacher engines, international partners were importing modular gas turbines, and state-owned companies were launching peak decentralised production programs. All this is a forced pragmatic reaction to blackouts and shortages of energy resources.

In parallel, the regulator adjusted the rules to the new reality. Separate procedures for ancillary services auctions appeared, where storage systems and fast generation can compete for long-term contracts. For wartime, this is a conservative, but timely and reliable innovation, according to which the market receives a clear signal, the operator receives a resource for system control, and the consumer can count on a stable energy supply and a decrease in the number of outages.

Hydrogen, ammonia and methanol: European logic – Ukrainian opportunities

The EU has laid the basic conditions for a large hydrogen market. Support for production through auctions, unified methods for confirming the origin of “green” hydrogen and recognition of low-carbon hydrogen are the market rules that were missing yesterday. Further, regulation covers transport: shipping receives an obligation to reduce carbon fuel intensity, aviation – minimal shares of sustainable fuels. At this stage, hydrogen derivatives – e-methanol and “green” ammonia – come into play.

E-methanol is synthesised from hydrogen and carbon dioxide using renewable electricity, while ammonia is produced from hydrogen and nitrogen from the air. These are liquid energy carriers that are easier to store and transport using the existing bulk infrastructure, so in the transitional years, they become a practical bridge between hydrogen producers and consumers, starting from the chemical industry and the agricultural sector and ending with shipping and aviation.

Ukraine can integrate into this chain from two sides. The first is infrastructure: we have port and chemical assets on the Black Sea, including the Odessa Port Plant, which traditionally worked with ammonia. Its privatisation track in 2025 creates a platform for a restart for “green” products after the war, and not only for classic fertilisers. The second is hydrogen derivative production projects in the logic of future export flows. Investors should make decisions about this, and the regulatory background is already clear, thanks to European rules and Ukrainian policies in the field of hydrogen energy.

For general clarity, it should be noted that we are not ahead of events. Even in Europe, e-methanol projects are only moving from pilots to industrial scales this year. But right now, a “demand funnel” is forming – from ports and logistics to shipping and aviation. Entering it with the right timing means getting a solvent buyer and financing for the export logistics.

Investment instruments in war: what works in practice

Classical investment instruments continue to operate, but with a risk adjustment. Project financing with guarantees from international financial institutions, political risk insurance, blending grants and loans, long-term power purchase agreements and system services are what drive new projects even under fire. When it comes to critical infrastructure, banks and donors are becoming co-investors in resilience, not just lenders. For example, package financing for peak generation and storage systems, which international development banks approved in 2025, was precisely a response to the lack of flexibility and winter risks.

An important nuance remains the networks. The development of data centres and electrification in Europe has already raised the bar for connection requirements and demand management. Demand is growing, and the window for connections is narrowing. For Ukraine, this is also a signal that every new megawatt of wind or solar must immediately receive a place in the network and a contract for flexibility. Otherwise, investors will not pay for generation, but for downtime.

Corruption scandals: not verdicts, but risk premiums

Recent months have given the market several high-profile stories with the arrests of top officials in the energy sector. Together with our lawyer colleagues, we do not give legal assessments and do not substitute for the court. We look at this as a risk factor. For international partners, this adds a premium to the cost of capital, complicates the structure of deals and increases the role of prior conditions: audits, compliance, and transparency of procurement. If a country shows that investigations are going to the top and are being completed procedurally correctly, investors take this into account and return to the project figures. If the turbulence is systemic, the share of grant components increases, and debt resources become more expensive. This is the logic of investment and the mathematics of risk in wartime.

Lessons from the Balkans: What the experience of Croatia and its neighbours says

After the wars of the 1990s, the countries of the former Yugoslavia went through a very similar cycle. First, stabilisation and large-scale intergovernmental initiatives like the Stability Pact, which, under pressure from the EU and international banks, opened up financing specifically for infrastructure. Then came privatisation and the long, sometimes painful modernisation of utility and energy assets, which attracted private capital only after the emergence of clear rules and regulatory safeguards. Croatia came to this through institutional reforms and European integration requirements, and investments in networks and generation were a consequence, not a cause. This is not idealisation, but a useful road map for us, focused on a different paradigm, based on the principle of “first rules and networks, then large-scale investments”.

Forecast for 2026: more networks, more flexibility, more hydrogen

A realistic scenario for Ukraine for 2026 consists of three mandatory elements.

The first is networks and connections. Europe is doubling down on interconnectors and internal lines because, without them, it will not be able to sustain either renewables or data centres. We need our own accelerated grid reconstruction plan with a priority for the rapid connection of new generation and storage facilities, like the Energy Infrastructure Plan for Europe. In the long term, this is cheaper than chronic outages.

The second is flexibility as a business. Portfolio storage systems, fast peaking stations, demand management and new ancillary services markets are not a temporary solution for wartime, but a new reality. Transmission system operator contracts, a clear auction schedule and seamless integration with European regulations, that’s where the difference between projects on paper and commissioned capacities lies.

Third – hydrogen derivatives, ammonia, e-methanol, as an export strategy. We should not compete for the “greenest hydrogen in the world” tomorrow. It is worth laying the foundation for the export of products that are easier to export and for which buyers are already appearing, namely e-methanol and “green” ammonia. This requires solutions that ensure transparent privatisation and reprofiling of port and chemical assets, transparent access to networks, and contractual bridges with European consumers. The rules in the EU already exist, and our strategies are currently under open discussion. Time is pressing, but it does not punish those who act systematically and consistently.

What this means for business and politics

For investors, the signal is simple. Ukrainian energy after 2025 is about networks and flexibility in connection with long-term contracts, plus niche industries based on hydrogen derivatives, where the region can become the production arm of the EU. The cost of capital will depend on the quality of risk management, not just on the scale of assets. The key for politicians will be to quickly create a regulatory framework between national and European legislation, protect competition in auctions and make export logistics predictable.

For citizens, the most important thing is the availability of energy resources and the ease of commissioning energy-efficient solutions. Everything else is just a way to achieve this. Ukraine enters 2026 with the experience of survival and a set of working solutions. Europe is shaping the demand for green electricity, diversifying its sources of natural gas and oil, and developing new markets for hydrogen and its derivatives. At the intersection of these two trajectories lies what we call an opportunity, which Ukraine has a chance to seize.

title: Bioethanol to jet fuel | Biofuels International Magazine
description:
The larger ethanol molecule yields the heavier kerosene fraction that is required for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
At a global level, the price of these nutritional commodities is being driven up by their competing use as a fuel.
Syngas derived from biomass gasification is CO-rich and is an ideal feedstock for the LanzaTech process.
As an alternative to power generation or flaring, utilisation of the BFG and BOFG in the LanzaTech process can generate ethanol.
Dehydration of ethanol on the way to produce kerosene Ethanol is an alcohol based on two carbon atoms.
text:
The conversion of methanol and ethanol to hydrocarbon fuels has been done for many years. The two dominant pathways are methanol to gasoline (MTG) and ethanol to jet (ETJ), which is also known as ethanol to kerosene (ETK), writes Stephen B. Harrison, Managing Director at sbh4 consulting, Germany.

.The smaller methanol molecule is ideal to produce the lighter gasoline fraction for cars. The larger ethanol molecule yields the heavier kerosene fraction that is required for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

Plant-based bio-ethanol

Traditionally, bioethanol has been produced from fermentation of sugary broths at industrial scale. The process is essentially the same as making beer from grain and then distilling the beer to make whisky.

In Asia and the Americas, the most widely used crops for bio-ethanol production are maize and sugar cane. Rice, sorghum and cassava are also used in secondary quantities. In Europe, these crops are generally replaced by wheat and sugar-beet.

Considering these crops, it is evident that agricultural land and food crops are being diverted to the production of biofuels as affordable energy vectors. At a global level, the price of these nutritional commodities is being driven up by their competing use as a fuel. For the rich, a few cents more for a kilo of wheat or rice will not drive a family into starvation. For impoverished nations, the same is not true.

The need for alternative non-food sources of sustainable ethanol is a global imperative. And, if it can also be produced from industrial emissions, this will surely be a win-win scenario.

Industrial ethanol from recycled carbon

The US company LanzaTech utilises anaerobic acetobacter bacteria in a fermenter to convert carbon monoxide (CO) rich feed gases, such as syngas, to ethanol and a range of biochemicals. The term CCT or ‘Carbon Capture and Transformation’ has been used to describe the LanzaTech fermentation process.

The ideal feedstocks for the LanzaTech fermenter are CO-rich. Syngas derived from biomass gasification is CO-rich and is an ideal feedstock for the LanzaTech process.

Iron and steel making also yields CO-rich flue gases. Blast furnace gas (BFG) contains 20% CO and converter gas (also known as basic oxygen furnace gas or BOFG) contains 60% CO.

At present, the energy rich BOFG (LHV 3 kWh/Nm3) is often utilised on the iron and steel making facility for heat or power generation on a gas engine. Alternatively, it is flared. BFG has a lower energy value because it contains less CO (LHV 0.9 kWh/Nm3). It can also be utilised for heat and power generation, or is sent to the flare.

As an alternative to power generation or flaring, utilisation of the BFG and BOFG in the LanzaTech process can generate ethanol. Subsequently, the complimentary LanzaJet process can be used to convert the ethanol to SAF in their proprietary ETJ process.

Lifecycle analysis

The LanzaTech bioreactor utilises CO from syngas to grow bacterial biomass in the fermenter. Some gases are emitted from the fermenter. This biomass from the fermenter is subsequently converted to biomethane in a separate anaerobic sludge digester. This energy-rich biomethane which is used to fully combust the main fermenter off gases to CO2. This CO2 can either then be emitted to the air or captured.

Life cycle analysis (LCA) of the LanzaTech process shows that CO2 emissions reduction is primarily due to the substitution of fossil fuels or crude-oil derived plastics with biomaterials produced from ethanol or other co-products recovered from the fermentation broth.

Also integral to the LanzaTech LCA is consideration of whether the feedstock, such as iron and steel making flue gases are flared, or utilised. If they are flared, their recovery and conversion to ethanol is a significant environmental benefit. However, if they are utilised to make heat and power, they already avoid the use of fossil fuels and the overall CO2 reduction in the LCA is reduced.

Scaling up successfully

LanzaTech’s process was demonstrated at pilot-scale in 2008 using flue gases from the BlueScope Steel mill in Glenbrook, NZ. Since then, LanzaTech has successfully deployed its technology at two 300 tonne per annum demonstration facilities at Baosteel Shanghai and Shougang Steel Caofeidian in China. These LanzaTech fermenters are fed with a range of iron and steel making off gases including BOFG, BFG, and coke oven gas (COG).

LanzaTech also operates the Freedom Pines Biorefinery in Soperton, Georgia which uses bio fermenters to generate ethanol and other chemicals. The LanzaJet ETJ SAF production process has also been implemented at that location.

Dehydration of ethanol on the way to produce kerosene

Ethanol is an alcohol based on two carbon atoms. As an alcohol, it contains an oxygen atom. Kerosene, on the other hand, is a long paraffinic hydrocarbon with between 10 and 14 carbon atoms that contains no oxygen.

Conversion of ethanol to kerosene takes place in two separate stages. The first is dehydration of ethanol to ethylene, or ethene. This effectively removes the oxygen atom and builds a highly reactive double bond linkage between the two carbon atoms.

The dehydration reaction is effected using a zeolite type catalyst such as H-ZSM-5 at between 250 and 300 °C. Low pressure operation is preferred to enable the production of gaseous ethylene. The reaction requires a very high heat input. This is a parasitic load on the process that consumes some of the energy of the feedstock to enable the conversion to kerosene.

Ethylene oligomerisation

The ethylene produced by the dehydration of ethanol is like a mouse trap, waiting to spring open. As the double bond between the two carbon atoms bond snaps open, it reaches out for another ethylene molecule to build butene a longer hydrocarbon containing four carbon atoms.

The conversion of ethylene to butene takes place over a nickel-based catalyst and releases a significant amount of heat, which can support the dehydration reaction.

Butene also contains a highly reactive carbon double bond. When several butene molecules are combined, very long hydrocarbons are created in a polymerisation reaction. If this reaction were left to proceed, the product would be polyethylene, a plastic polymer. To produce kerosene, the reaction must be initiated and then curtailed. This partial polymerisation is known as oligomerisation.

The oligomerisation proceeds using another zeolite catalyst such as ZSM-5. If it is conducted at high temperature, branched isomers of kerosene can be produced. These are desirable because they allow the fuel to be used at low temperatures (such as those at altitude) without freezing.

Hydrotreating and fractionation

The synthetic crude (syncrude) produced by oligomerisation may still contain some residual oxygen atoms from the ethanol feedstock. These must be removed to prevent corrosion of materials handling and storing the kerosene, and to prevent polymerisation of the fuel.

Hydrogen is reacted with the syncrude to remove oxygen and convert it into water. The deoxygenated syncrude is then distilled into fractions such as gasoline, diesel and kerosene for SAF.

The economics can be optimised by tailoring the process conditions to produce the most valuable fuel, which is SAF.

title: Demand for rapeseed imports declined due to an improved supply situation in the EU
description:
According to European Commission estimates, the rapeseed harvest in the EU-27 totalled around 20.16 million tonnes in 2025.
This translates to a significant increase in supply compared to the previous year's substandard 16.77 million tonnes.
With the rapeseed processing volume expected to reach around 24.68 million tonnes, it also makes the EU less dependent on imports.
By contrast, Moldova and Serbia ramped up their deliveries significantly compared to the first half of the crop year 2024/25, supplying 247,357 tonnes (previous year: 85,611 tonnes) and 114,171 tonnes (previous year: 44,501 tonnes), respectively.
Some of the rapeseed imports declared as Moldovan are likely to be of Ukrainian origin, reflecting changes in transit and trade routes.
text:
According to European Commission estimates, the rapeseed harvest in the EU-27 totalled around 20.16 million tonnes in 2025.

This translates to a significant increase in supply compared to the previous year's substandard 16.77 million tonnes.

With the rapeseed processing volume expected to reach around 24.68 million tonnes, it also makes the EU less dependent on imports.

Cumulative imports into the EU-27 in the first half of the crop year 2025/26 amounted to approximately 1.85 million tonnes, representing a nearly 43 per cent decline from the previous year's level of 3.23 million tonnes.

Ukraine remains the leading supplier country with just over 1.06 million tonnes to date and a 57 per cent share of imports. Nevertheless, the country's shipments remain clearly below the previous year's volume of 2.02 million tonnes.

The second wave of imports from Australia will increasingly come into focus later on in the season. By January, Australia had placed 249,869 tonnes of rapeseed on the EU market, ranking second among the major countries of origin with a share of just under 14 per cent, but trailing well behind Ukraine. According to investigations conducted by Agrarmarkt Informations-Gesellschaft (mbH), deliveries remained approximately 71 per cent below the level recorded in the reference period.

Canada continued to lose market share.

The country delivered 140,915 tonnes of rapeseed to date, which compares to 161,347 tonnes the previous year.

Because Canadian farmers grow genetically modified varieties, the use of rapeseed oil derived from Canadian rapeseed is restricted in the EU. As a result, imports from Canada are primarily used for biofuel production.

By contrast, Moldova and Serbia ramped up their deliveries significantly compared to the first half of the crop year 2024/25, supplying 247,357 tonnes (previous year: 85,611 tonnes) and 114,171 tonnes (previous year: 44,501 tonnes), respectively. Some of the rapeseed imports declared as Moldovan are likely to be of Ukrainian origin, reflecting changes in transit and trade routes.

description:

text:
DICKINSON — On Wednesday at the Biesiot Activities Center, the North Dakota State University (NDSU) Dickinson Extension Center hosted its 29th annual “Diversity, Direction and Dollars” Ag Forum. The event was open to the public and included six presentations by researchers and market experts.

Doors opened at 8:30, and after a welcome from KDIX Radio’s Mike Renner, Chris Augustin, director of the Dickinson Research Extension Center, took the floor for his presentation, “Acid Soil Management in North Dakota No-till Soils.”

During his talk, Augustin gave a rundown on the basics of soil acidity and pH, mainly differentiating soil salinity or solidicity from soil acidity, which has to do with the concentration of hydrogen. Augustin explained that as soil pH decreases, that means that soil acidity increases. One of Augustin’s main points was that when soil pH measures as low as 5.5, that should register immediate concern. According to his research, incorporating lime into acidic soils helps to neutralize it.

Following Augustin was Chandler Mazour, who is a Nebraska native and product manager for GEVO and Verity Tracking. Mazour’s talk was titled “Carbon Intensity Counts: Monetizing Farm-Level Data.”

Mazour’s company acquired the Red Trail Energy facility in Richardton last year, and part of his presentation updated the crowd on that project, including the “carbon capture and sequestration efforts,” Mazour said. In the long term, it is GEVO’s goal to produce sustainable aviation fuel at their Richardton location. Mazour also said that his company is building out a grower program, working directly with farmers who want to track the carbon intensity of their own grain.

For the last presentation of the morning session, the forum welcomed Tommy Grisafi as its keynote speaker. Grisafi is a Risk Advisor and Commodity Broker for Advance Trading Inc., and is the owner of Ag Bull Media, which produces a popular agricultural podcast by the same name. Grisafi’s presentation was geared toward the risk management side of farming.

In addition to his own musings on stocks and market prices, Grisafi shared some observations he has made over the years of successful grain marketers and offered some practical advice for emulating their tactics, such as not second guessing one’s decisions, and not being afraid to invest in new technologies or equipment.

Following lunch, Frayne Olson, Crops Economist for NDSU, opened the afternoon session with his talk, “Buckle Up! 2026 Crop Market and Trade Outlook.” Olson shared several tables and graphs with the crowd, specifically focusing on the outlook for corn, soybean and wheat growers, comparing projections for the US market. He also covered US exports, with major buyers of US grains found in China, Mexico, Japan and Egypt.

The final two presentations were given by Joe Ikley, NDSU Extension Weed Specialist and Kevin Sedivec, who presented his talk entitled, “Is Virtual Fence the Future of Grazing Management: Pros and Cons.” Ikley went through the weed guide for this year during his presentation, “Herbicide Resistant Weeds and Best Practice Strategies for Control.”

text:
Ottawa, Jan. 15, 2026 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The global sustainable paper chemicals market size was estimated at USD 40.19 billion in 2025 and is expected to increase from USD 41.98 billion in 2026 to USD 62.12 billion by 2035, growing at a CAGR of 4.45% from 2026 to 2035. In terms of volume, the market is projected to grow from 14,650.00 tons in 2025 to 20,440.10 tons by 2035. growing at a CAGR of 3.34% from 2026 to 2035. Asia Pacific dominated the sustainable paper chemicals market with the largest volume share of 43.00% in 2025. The market is driven by demand for eco-friendly packaging, strict environmental regulations, and a shift towards advanced, non-toxic chemical formulations. A study published by Towards Chemical and Materials a sister firm of Precedence Research.

Download a Sample Report Here@ https://www.towardschemandmaterials.com/download-sample/6134

What is Going on in the Sustainable Paper Chemicals Industry?

The rising awareness of environmental and climatic challenges, stringent environmental regulations, and growing push toward the circular economy initiative are reinforcing the shift towards sustainable formulation. Additionally, the global consumer preference for eco-friendly solutions is boosting demand for sustainable alternatives in paper manufacturing.

Request Research Report Built Around Your Goals: sales@towardschemandmaterials.com

Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market Report Highlights

The Asia Pacific dominated the global sustainable paper chemicals market with the largest volume share of 43.00% in 2025.

The sustainable paper chemicals market in North America is expected to grow at a substantial CAGR of 4.76% from 2026 to 2035.

The Europe sustainable paper chemicals market segment accounted for the major volume share of 23.50% in 2025.

By product type, the functional sustainable chemicals segment dominated the market and accounted for the largest volume share of 50.12% in 2025.

By product type, the pulping & sustainable bleaching agents segment is expected to grow at the fastest CAGR of 4.27% from 2026 to 2035.

By raw material, the plant-based polysaccharides (Starch) segment led the market with the largest revenue volume share of 45% in 2025.

By end use, the food and beverage packaging segment dominated the market and accounted for the largest volume share of 38.2% in 2025.

Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market Report Scope

Major Government Initiatives for the Sustainable Paper Chemicals Industry:

Green Chemistry R&D Initiative: The Indian Government's Principal Scientific Adviser identifies the pulp and paper industry as a priority sector for developing a roadmap for sustainable R&D interventions.

Production-Linked Incentive (PLI) Scheme: This scheme offers financial benefits to boost domestic chemical manufacturing, incentivising the production of high-performance and eco-friendly specialty chemicals.

Ecomark Rules: Notified by the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change, these rules encourage demand for environmentally friendly paper products and sustainable production processes.

Chemical Promotion Development Scheme (CPDS): This initiative provides grants-in-aid to conduct workshops and research on green technologies and chemical safety within the industry.

Petrochemicals Research & Innovation Commendation (PRIC) Scheme: The government felicitates and rewards innovations in sustainable polymers and green manufacturing processes.

Centres of Excellence (CoE) for Sustainable Polymers: Specialized research centres provide funding to develop biodegradable polymers and bio-engineered materials as alternatives to traditional chemical additives.

Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) Guidelines: These guidelines mandate that producers of paper packaging take responsibility for collection and recycling, driving the adoption of recyclable chemical coatings and adhesives.

National BioE3 Policy: This policy fosters high-performance biomanufacturing to promote sustainable packaging materials, reducing dependency on fossil-fuel-based chemicals.

What Are the Major Trends inthe Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market?

Enzymatic & Microbial Processing: The major shift towards targeted enzymes and microbial feedstocks lowers energy and water consumption with improved fiber quality for high-performance applications.

Sustainability and Eco-Friendly Solutions: The increasing focus on reducing environmental impact and strict regulations is driving the adoption of green chemistry principles, bio-based and sustainable chemicals, and low-toxicity chemicals.

PFAS-Free Bio-based Coatings: Driven by manufacturers' implementation in biodegradable and compostable barrier coatings. Innovations in bio-based coatings provide grease and moisture resistance for food packaging without compromising recyclability.

Market Dynamics

Driver

The global push towards zero-waste manufacturing is driving the circular economy market, which enables repeated recycling cycles. With the rise in e-commerce, new specialized resins and retention have been developed to maintain the structural integrity of paper through multiple recycling cycles, supporting zero-waste production goals.

Restraint

The high production costs and raw material price volatility restrain the market. The manufacturing cost of eco-friendly, bio-based chemicals is higher than conventional chemicals. Additionally, the industry is challenged by a lack of reliable supply of raw material, restraining the market growth.

Market Opportunity

Which Bio-Materials Offer the Best Commercial Scalability?

The growing focus on industrial-scale production of seaweed extract, nanocellulose (MFC), and polyhydroxyalkanoate (PHA) provides high grease resistance used in commercial-scale like home-compostable in food service and packaging solutions with improved performance for moisture resistance, durability, and printability.

Can Digital Innovation& Technological Shift Ensure Long-term Profitability and the Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market Leadership?

The industry is integrating AI-driven control systems, IoT sensors, and digital twins to provide real-time monitoring and automated, precise chemical dosing, which improves efficiency, minimizes waste, and ensures consistent product quality. The technological shift driving the development of press-applied aqueous dispersions and precision coating systems which accelerating the adoption of PFAS-free solutions.

Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market Segmentation Insights

By Chemical Function & Product Type Insights

Why did the Functional Sustainable Chemicals Segment Dominate the Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market in 2025?

The functional sustainable chemicals dominated the market due to their essential role in making high-performance, durable paper products as an additive. As the global drive to replace single-use plastics with sustainable paper alternatives. These chemicals enhance properties like superior strength, printability, and moisture resistance, vital for packaging and hygiene products. Growing environmental regulations and consumer demand for sophisticated functional sustainable chemicals drive continuous growth across application sectors.

The pulping & sustainable bleaching agents’ segment is anticipated to grow fastest in the market during the forecast period. propelled by strict environmental laws, increasing use of innovative enzymatic solutions, and a push to eliminate chlorinated compounds through eco-friendly processes like elemental chlorine-free processes that depend on oxygen, ozone, and hydrogen peroxide, boosting process efficiency, reducing energy consumption, and reducing pollution.

Raw Material Insights

Which Raw Material Segment Held the Dominating Share of the Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market in 2025?

The plant-based polysaccharides (Starch) segment dominated the market, owing to their versatility, cost-effectiveness, and eco-friendliness. This segment is utilized in the papermaking process, acting as a bonding agent and sizing agent to improve fiber retention. They enhance paper strength, smoothness, and printability without adverse impacts, thereby supporting recycling and circular economy goals.

The microbial/biotech feedstocks segment is set to experience the fastest growth, driven by the emergence of precision sustainability and advanced biomanufacturing utilizing engineered microorganisms and an enzymatic system to produce precise, biodegradable chemicals from industrial waste. This reduces raw material use and supports sustainable, zero-waste production.

End Use Insights

How did the Food & Beverage Packaging Segment hold the Largest Share of the Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market?

The food & beverage packaging segment dominated the market due to massive industrial demand for performance-driven packaging solutions and is supported by strict environmental regulations. High demand for safe, biodegradable solutions like greaseproof and moisture barriers, driven by the shift from plastics and the growth of e-commerce and food delivery services, which require durable, recyclable, and sustainable paper formats, solidifies this segment's leading position in chemical consumption.

The E-commerce & logistics segment is expected to grow at the fastest CAGR during the projected period. The growth fueled by online shopping has created a massive demand for durable, lightweight, and eco-friendly paperboard. Sustainable chemicals enhance paper properties such as compression strength and shock resistance without adding weight, promoting recyclable solutions that meet consumer and regulatory needs that boosting rapid innovation and consumption.

Regional Insights

The Asia Pacific sustainable paper chemicals market size was valued at USD 17.38 billion in 2025 and is expected to be worth around USD 26.83 billion by 2035, exhibiting at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 6.65% over the forecast period from 2026 to 2035. the sustainable paper chemicals market volume was estimated at 6,299.5 tons in 2025 and is projected to reach 8,407.0 tons by 2035, growing at a CAGR of 3.26% from 2026 to 2035. Asia Pacific dominated the sustainable paper chemicals market with 43.0% share in 2025, due to the ongoing heavy paper production and packaging demand.

Howdid Asia Pacific Dominate the Global Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market?

The Asia Pacific region leads the global market due to rapid industrial growth, increased paper demand, and environmental policies. Urbanization, e-commerce expansion, and government incentives are driving demand for eco-friendly, bio-based chemicals, replacing traditional petroleum-based options. The government's stringent environmental regulations and significant paper production capacity of this region lead to a market position.

China Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market Trends

China dominates with its vast manufacturing hub, rapid urbanization, and strict environmental regulations, boosting demand for advanced bio-based chemicals to produce high-performance recyclable products. The innovations, including waterless stone paper and consumer preferences, are accelerating market expansion.

Why is North America the Fastest-Growing Region in the Sustainable Paper Chemicals Industry?

North America is rapidly growing, supported by strict regulations, sophisticated infrastructure, and a consumer shift toward eco-friendly packaging. The region's focus on R&D and biotech innovations, such as enzymatic processing, enhances sustainable, low-impact production, aligns with global goals.

U.S. Sustainable Paper Chemicals Market Trends

The U.S. market is primarily driven by stringent environmental regulations, strong consumer demand for eco-friendly products, and the increasing e-commerce sector's demand for sustainable packaging solutions. The regulation, combined with technological innovation and investment uplifting the market.

title: [SMM Hydrogen Industry Weekly Review] 20260115 - Metal News

It is understood that Package A includes 60 hydrogen-powered vehicles (50 four-stage sweeping vehicles [hydrogen fuel cell four-season sweeping vehicles], 5 low-pressure sprinklers [hydrogen fuel cell sprinklers], and 5 high-pressure flushing sprinklers [hydrogen fuel cell sprinklers (high-pressure flushing)]).
Major equipment includes water electrolysis hydrogen production units, hydrogen purification equipment, hydrogen compressors, hydrogen storage tanks, hydrogen refueling station equipment, transformers, ESS equipment, and closed-cycle cooling water systems.
Guangdong Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Technology Co., Ltd.: The Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Pazhou Hydrogen Refueling Station has been approved.
Guangdong Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Technology Co., Ltd.:The Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Nankiangshan Service Area East Hydrogen Refueling Station has been approved.
Among these, the fixed hydrogen storage is calculated at 345kg (one set of 12m2 hydrogen storage bottle group), with a hydrogen storage pressure no greater than 45MIPa.
text:
I. Policy Review: Hydrogen Energy Policy Developments

(I) Domestic Policies

Shanghai Municipal Commission of Economy and Informatization:Issued the "Notice on Carrying out the Application for Reward Funds for the Demonstration Operation of Fuel Cell Vehicles in Shanghai." The core hydrogen-related content of the document is as follows: The supported areas focus on the demonstration application of fuel cell vehicles, providing special rewards for the operation of fuel cell trucks and commercial commuter buses; The reward criteria are clear: eligible vehicles that travel more than 20,000 kilometers within each assessment year are eligible for rewards, accumulating up to a maximum of 3 years from the date of obtaining the operation quota. Specifically, trucks with a total design mass of 12-31 tons (inclusive) receive an annual reward of 5,000 yuan, heavy trucks with a total design mass exceeding 31 tons receive an annual reward of 20,000 yuan, and commuter buses receive an annual reward of 10,000 yuan; The reward funds are sourced from municipal finance and the district finance where the vehicle operating enterprise is located, shared in a 1:1 ratio; Four assessment years are specified, with the fourth assessment year ending on December 31, 2025, covering multiple years of fuel cell vehicle operation cycles. Previously, Shanghai had issued documents such as the "Several Policy Measures to Support the Accelerated Development of the City's Fuel Cell Vehicle Industry" (Hu Gai Gui Fan [2021] No. 10) and the "Detailed Rules for the Implementation of Special Funds for the Demonstration Application of Fuel Cell Vehicles in Shanghai" (Hu Jing Xin Gui Fan [2023] No. 2). This "Notice" is a continuation and implementation of the aforementioned policies, forming a complete policy chain of "industrial support policies + fund implementation rules + application notice" by clarifying the application process, standards, and time requirements for operation rewards, continuously promoting the large-scale demonstration application of Shanghai's fuel cell vehicle (one of the core application scenarios for hydrogen energy) industry.

Liaoning Provincial Department of Transport:Issued the "Implementation Plan for Optimizing the Business Environment in the Liaoning Provincial Transport Industry for 2026." The document points out that the province announced the list of key construction projects for 2026. The list clearly includes 15 key hydrogen industry projects, covering 3 new projects to start construction and 12 projects under continued construction, involving key links across the entire industry chain such as hydrogen production, hydrogen storage, equipment manufacturing, and end-use applications. New projects to start construction (3 items): Hebei Feitian Future 300,000 mt/year Sustainable Energy Hydrogen Refueling Integration Project; Hebei Hechen Hydrogen Cylinder Production Project (Feixiang District); North China Petrochemical 100,000 mt/year Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Project (Renqiu City). Projects under continued construction (12 items): CSSC Wind Power Hydrogen Production, Storage, Application and ESS Equipment R&D and Manufacturing Base Project (Xingtai Economic Development Zone); CSSC Peric Hydrogen Energy Equipment Industrial Park Construction Phase I Project (Handan Economic Development Zone); Tangshan Yue'an Hydrogen-Electric New Energy Qian'an Hydrogen-Electric Comprehensive Energy Station (Qian'an City); Zhongneng Yida (Hebei) New Energy New 400,000 mt/year Sustainable Aviation Fuel Hydrogenation Project (Shenze County); Handan Fengda Cixian Coal Mining Subsidence Area Wind and Solar Power + ESS + Hydrogen Integration Base Project Phase I (200MW Guaranteed Wind Power) (Cixian County); Hebei Dexin Hydrogen Energy Technology Coke Oven Gas Hydrogen Production Comprehensive Utilization Project (She County); Energy China Green Hydrogen China Energy Construction Group Shijiazhuang Luquan District PV Hydrogen Production and Hydrogen Energy Supporting Industry Project (Luquan District); Guiyan New Energy Hydrogen Energy Industry Base Project (Qinhuangdao Haigang District); Hebei Zhongrui Automobile Hydrogen Fuel Cell and New Energy Special Vehicle Project (Wei County); Sunrise Power Hydrogen Energy Equipment Industrial Park (Wu'an Enclave) Project Phase I (Hanshan District); Hebei Fengmei Coking Coke Oven Gas Hydrogen Production Co-production SNG Construction Project (Fengfeng Mining Area); Hebei Xuyang Energy Co., Ltd. 5 mt/day Liquid Hydrogen Demonstration Project (Dingzhou City). The document proposes that in optimizing differentiated toll policies for expressways, it clearly continues to implement the policy of free passage for hydrogen fuel cell trucks, advancing in parallel with differentiated policies for port container transport vehicles, Class 6 (axle) trucks, Class 5 (axle) trucks, etc. By reducing the passage costs for hydrogen fuel cell trucks, it aids the promotion and application of hydrogen energy in the transportation sector.

(II) Overseas Trends

Nimbus Power Systems: announced the successful completion of shock and vibration tests for Nimbus's advanced, gravity-independent fuel cell technology, a key milestone for future human spaceflight. These tests simulated the expected mechanical loads of NASA's upcoming Artemis manned lunar landing mission, including launch. Throughout the testing, the fuel cell met all performance targets, demonstrating the system's structural and operational readiness, preparing it for future flight integration.

Gascade Gastransport: German natural gas operator Gascade Gastransport stated it completed the initial filling of the pipeline sections constituting the "North-South Axis" of the joint Flow project, involving the conversion of a total of 400 kilometers of natural gas pipeline to transport hydrogen. Reportedly, this pipeline starts from Lubmin and connects to Bobbau in Saxony-Anhalt.

Volkswagen (VW): will install a small electrolysis system at its Poznań plant in Poland to supply hydrogen for a 1.5MW gas burner. The project is expected to reduce fuel consumption by up to 30% and lower on-site carbon emissions. The system will be provided by Bulgarian hydrogen technology company Hydrogenera, which will deliver and install a 90kW alkaline electrolyzer that will produce hydrogen and oxygen for injection into the burner.

II. Enterprise Dynamics: Project Signings and Technical Cooperation

(I) Project Intelligence

Jiangsu Provincial Port Group Co., Ltd.: Jiangsu Provincial Port Group Co., Ltd. released the 2026-2027 Annual Electric Heavy-Duty Truck Supplier Centralized Qualification Project. The hydrogen energy heavy-duty truck section of this project includes hydrogen energy tractors. Through this public tender, no more than three suppliers will be pre-qualified, and procurement guidance prices for the agreement period will be determined. Pre-qualified suppliers will sign a supply framework agreement with the bid inviter; subsequently, based on the procurement needs of the bid inviter and its subordinate units, specific procurement contracts or orders will be signed with the pre-qualified suppliers, and payment settlements will be conducted. The bid inviter does not commit to awarding actual supply contracts to pre-qualified suppliers during the pre-qualification validity period, nor does it commit to the total value of supply contracts awarded within the year. Shortlisted suppliers shall not reject the supply invitations from the bid inviter and its subordinate units for any reason; otherwise, the bid inviter shall have the right to disqualify them from the shortlist.

Tangshan Yue'an Hydrogen and Electricity New Energy Technology Co., Ltd.: The winning bid result for the sanitation new energy vehicle renewal project (Phase I) of Tangshan Yue'an Hydrogen and Electricity New Energy Technology Co., Ltd. has been announced. The bid winner is Shijiazhuang Coal Mine Machinery Co., Ltd., with a total bid price of 90.7 million yuan and a delivery date requiring completion of all project work within 2 months after signing the contract. It is understood that Package A includes 60 hydrogen-powered vehicles (50 four-stage sweeping vehicles [hydrogen fuel cell four-season sweeping vehicles], 5 low-pressure sprinklers [hydrogen fuel cell sprinklers], and 5 high-pressure flushing sprinklers [hydrogen fuel cell sprinklers (high-pressure flushing)]).

GAC Lingcheng New Energy Commercial Vehicle Co., Ltd.: GAC Lingcheng held a grand ceremony for the batch delivery of hydrogen fuel cell vehicles themed "Gathering Strength in the Bay Area, Creating a Hydrogen Future" at its Conghua factory in Guangzhou. It is understood that a total of 340 hydrogen fuel cell vehicles were delivered this time.

Zhizi Automobile Technology Co., Ltd.: Fifty hydrogen-powered heavy trucks from Zhizi Automobile were officially delivered to Yulin and put into operation. These delivered vehicles are equipped with Zhizi Automobile's self-developed 215 kW fuel cell system and an 8×385L large-capacity hydrogen supply system, filling the application gap for long-driving range hydrogen-powered heavy trucks in the Yulin region.

Shaanxi Xuqiangrui Clean Energy Group Co., Ltd.: The second batch of 20 hydrogen-powered heavy trucks was officially delivered and put into operation. It is understood that these hydrogen-powered heavy trucks are equipped with large-power hydrogen fuel cell stack products independently developed and mass-produced by Xuqiangrui Group's subsidiary, Shaanxi Xuqing Times Technology Co., Ltd. They adopt a "dual 78 kW stack" architecture, providing stable and powerful power output, with a comprehensive driving range of 450–500 kilometers and a hydrogen consumption of only 8–9 kg per 100 kilometers.

Shaanxi Xuqing Times Technology Co., Ltd.: Twenty hydrogen-powered heavy trucks equipped with hydrogen fuel cell stacks independently developed and mass-produced by Xuqing Times were officially delivered and put into operation in Hancheng City, Shaanxi Province, to Xuqiangrui Group.

Weichai Power Co., Ltd.: Weichai's hydrogen internal combustion engine generator set successfully achieved the first stable operation of pure hydrogen power generation connected to the grid in China. This grid-connected Weichai hydrogen internal combustion engine generator set is located at the Wuxi Huaguang Energy Microgrid Demonstration Project.

Guangdong Aluminum Plant in Dongtang Town, Renhua County, Shaoguan City: The integrated hydrogen production and refueling station project of Guangdong Aluminum Plant has been approved for filing. The project is located at Guangdong Aluminum Plant in Dongtang Town, Renhua County, Shaoguan City, with a total investment of 180 million yuan. The construction unit is Shaoguan Gangcun Hydrogen Energy Technology Co., Ltd. This project involves the construction of an integrated hydrogen production and refueling station. Upon completion, the hydrogen production capacity is expected to reach 2,500 kg/d, with a total hydrogen storage capacity of 2.5 mt. The project utilizes water electrolysis for hydrogen production. Major equipment includes water electrolysis hydrogen production units, hydrogen purification equipment, hydrogen compressors, hydrogen storage tanks, hydrogen refueling station equipment, transformers, ESS equipment, and closed-cycle cooling water systems. The project will be constructed in five phases, involving the installation of six sets of hydrogen production facilities along with auxiliary supporting facilities and utilities. Once operational, the integrated station will supply hydrogen to the hydrogen-powered vehicles of the parent company and will not engage in external commercial activities.

Guangdong Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Technology Co., Ltd.: The Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Pazhou Hydrogen Refueling Station has been approved. Located on a plot northwest of the Guangdong Fish Wheel Factory on Xingang East Road, Pazhou Street, Haizhu District, Guangzhou, the project has a total investment of 5 million yuan, with Guangdong Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Technology Co., Ltd. as the project unit. The project involves the construction of one skid-mounted hydrogen refueling station, with a hydrogen storage scale of 650 kg. The hydrogen storage facility consists of one tube trailer, and the refueling capacity is 1,000 kg. According to the "Technical Code for Hydrogen Refueling Stations" GB 50516-2010 (2021 edition), the station is classified as a Level III station. Major equipment within the station includes one hydrogen unloading column, one integrated compressor and refueling skid, and one set of nitrogen purging and instrument air system.

Guangdong Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Technology Co., Ltd.:The Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Nankiangshan Service Area East Hydrogen Refueling Station has been approved. Located at the hydrogen refueling station site in the East Area of the Nankiangshan Service Area on the Huaguan Expressway, Zengcheng District, Guangzhou, the project has a total investment of 8 million yuan, with Guangdong Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Technology Co., Ltd. as the project unit. This project involves the construction of one hydrogen refueling station, with a current designed daily hydrogen supply capacity of 1,000 kg/d. The total on-site hydrogen storage capacity is 700 kg (fixed storage + tube trailer storage). Among this, the fixed hydrogen storage capacity is calculated as 345 kg (one set of 12m² hydrogen storage cylinder bundles), with a storage pressure not exceeding 45 MPa. One tube trailer parking space is provided, accommodating one tube trailer with a hydrogen storage capacity of 355 kg per unit and a storage pressure not exceeding 30 MPa. According to the <> GB 50516-2010 (2021 edition), this hydrogen refueling station is classified as a Level III station.

Sinopec Huazhong Xiangtan Petroleum Branch:Hunan's first methanol refueling station—the Xiangtan Petroleum Zhutang Refueling Station—officially commenced operations. The station is located on National Highway 107, Xiangtan County, Xiangtan City.

(II) Enterprise Dynamics

SPIC Hydrogen Energy Technology Development Co., Ltd.:Guohydrogen Technology held a cadres meeting. Liu Feng, member of the Party Leadership Group and Deputy General Manager of the Group company, attended the meeting and delivered a speech. Gao Xiaoqiang, Deputy Director of the Group's Human Resources Department, presided over the meeting. At the meeting, Gao Xiaoqiang announced the construction plan for the green hydrogen-based energy industry platform and announced the relevant appointment and removal decisions of the Group Party Committee: Comrade Yang Yufeng was appointed as Party Committee Secretary of Guohydrogen Technology, concurrently recommended as a candidate for Chairman, and will undergo statutory procedures; Comrade Li Lianrong was appointed as Director of Guohydrogen Technology; Comrade Zhang Yinguang will temporarily be responsible for the daily work of the management team.

CIMC Hydrogen Energy Technology (Nantong) Co., Ltd.: Nantong Hydrogen successfully passed the national high-tech enterprise certification and was approved as a Nantong municipal enterprise technology center. It is understood that the company focuses on the application of hydrogen energy in transportation, with its main business being hydrogen vehicle cylinders and hydrogen supply systems. The production line has achieved automation and intelligence and is gradually transitioning to digitalization. The product applications cover vehicles, ships, drones, and specialized machinery.

Yingde Gases: The first 62,500Nm³/h air separation unit designed for Wanhua Chemical's Fujian Industrial Park "MDI Integrated Expansion Supporting Project - Gas Expansion and Renovation Project" recently passed the performance evaluation.

Shanghai Xinran Compressor Co., Ltd.: Released an AI-based [Artificial Intelligence (AI)] professional planning scheme for diaphragm compressors.

Xin Yan Hydrogen Energy Technology Co., Ltd.: The first hydrogen energy bus demonstration route in Fujian Province, Xiamen Line 736, jointly developed with Xiamen King Long, officially opened, with the core fuel cell system provided by Xin Yan Hydrogen.

Xin Yan Hydrogen Energy Technology Co., Ltd.: Yuntao Hydrogen Nanxiangshan Service Area East Zone Hydrogen Refueling Station received approval. The project is located at the Guangzhou Zengcheng District Huawan Expressway Nanxiangshan Service Area East Zone Hydrogen Refueling Station site, with a total investment of 8 million yuan, and the project entity is Guangdong Yuntao Hydrogen Energy Technology Co., Ltd. This project constructs one hydrogen refueling station, currently designed with a daily hydrogen supply capacity of 1,000kg/d; the total hydrogen storage within the station is 700kg (fixed hydrogen storage + long tube trailer hydrogen storage). Among these, the fixed hydrogen storage is calculated at 345kg (one set of 12m2 hydrogen storage bottle group), with a hydrogen storage pressure no greater than 45MIPa. There is one long tube trailer parking space, accommodating one long tube trailer, with a hydrogen storage capacity of 355kg/unit, and a hydrogen storage pressure no greater than 30MIPa. According to <> GB.50516-2010 (2021 edition), this project's hydrogen refueling station is classified as a level three station.

III. Technological Advancements: Breakthroughs in Efficiency and Cost

(i) Production, Storage, and Transportation Sectors

Beijing Hydrogen Innovation Center: At the "Hydrogen Heart Peer, Innovate for the Future" Beijing Hydrogen Innovation Center Achievements Release Conference, the Beijing Hydrogen Innovation Center released the forward design results of the heavy truck hydrogen-electric integrated chassis R&D project. Version 2.0 of the heavy truck achieved a hydrogen consumption of 7.1kg per 100km under plain conditions, and the vehicle can be flash-charged, completing the refueling in 10-15 minutes.

CIMC Enric: Its subsidiary, Shijiazhuang Enric Gas Machinery Co., Ltd., successfully launched the 38.7m³ Type II tube bundle container project product.

Chinese Academy of Sciences: The new technology of sprayed ultra-high performance concrete (SUHPC), jointly developed by CCCC Second Harbor Engineering Co., Ltd. and the Wuhan Institute of Rock and Soil Mechanics of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, was successfully applied in the initial tunnel support project of China's first rock cavern hydrogen energy storage system—the Daye Rock Cavern Hydrogen Energy Storage System in Hubei.

Foshan Xianhu Laboratory: The industry's first "zero-carbon ammonia-fueled aluminum billet heating furnace" for aluminum extrusion production was launched at Foshan Xianhu Laboratory. This equipment achieves zero-carbon operation in the aluminum processing heating stage, marking an important step forward in the green transformation of China's aluminum processing industry.

(II) Fuel Cell Technology/Product Updates

South China University of Technology: Research by Chen Yu's team discovered a Ce₀.₆Ni₀.₂Cu₀.₂O₂ nanocatalyst with a heterogeneous structure, which aids high-performance direct methanol protonic ceramic fuel cells.

Wuhan University of Technology: Professor Tang Haolin's team collaborated with Professor Jin Huanyu from the Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences. They proposed a strategy of "coupling electron-withdrawing groups to enhance proton delocalization," which reduces the proton delocalization energy barrier in perfluorosulfonimide-phenyl*acid (PFSI-BPA) membranes through molecular structure design, achieving synergistic improvement in efficient proton conduction and thermal stability, and this was confirmed through a combination of in situ measurements and theoretical calculations.

title: NewYork GreenCloud acquires California biomass plant for carbon-negative AI project
description:
NewYork GreenCloud (NYGC) has acquired the Buena Vista Biomass Power facility in Ione, California, marking a step toward developing what the company says will be its first large-scale carbon-negative artificial intelligence facility, reports Bioenergy Insight.
The site will integrate biomass-based pyrolysis power systems with on-site, liquid-cooled AI computing infrastructure.
This setup is intended to support high-performance AI workloads using renewable, round-the-clock energy generated at the facility.
The existing 18 MW biomass power plant will be expanded and converted into a 41 MW facility.
The upgraded plant is designed to provide continuous renewable electricity to an on-site AI factory, supporting next-generation graphics processing unit clusters.
text:
NewYork GreenCloud (NYGC) has acquired the Buena Vista Biomass Power facility in Ione, California, marking a step toward developing what the company says will be its first large-scale carbon-negative artificial intelligence facility, reports Bioenergy Insight.

The site will integrate biomass-based pyrolysis power systems with on-site, liquid-cooled AI computing infrastructure. This setup is intended to support high-performance AI workloads using renewable, round-the-clock energy generated at the facility.

NYGC Chief Executive Officer Joe Church said the acquisition marks the start of a broader national plan to develop carbon-negative AI facilities, adding that the project is aimed at delivering advanced computing capacity while sharply reducing environmental impact.

Redevelopment of the facility is being carried out jointly by NYGC and its engineering partner, BucSha Energy, which specialises in biomass-to-pyrolysis systems.

The existing 18 MW biomass power plant will be expanded and converted into a 41 MW facility. The upgraded plant is designed to provide continuous renewable electricity to an on-site AI factory, supporting next-generation graphics processing unit clusters.

BucSha Energy founder Dave Shaffer said the project places strong emphasis on the use of local biomass resources, noting that reliance on regional feedstock helps create a clean, reliable and scalable energy supply for modern computing needs.

Impact Capital Partners served as advisor on the transaction’s capital strategy and financing structure. Sandy Goodman, managing partner at the firm, said the acquisition offers a model for expanding sustainable and scalable computing infrastructure.

title: MSR&PC Interacts with Farmers at Winter Conferences - Morning Ag Clips
description:
For MSR&PC Director of Research Sergio Cabello Leiva, the northern Minnesota ramble was a return to his research roots.
“The Soil Management Summit is a great opportunity for farmers, ag professionals and scientists to get together and talk about sustainability and protecting our soils,” said Cabello Leiva, who joined MSR&PC in spring 2025.
The MN Organic Conference was unique in that it spearheaded conversations and interactions with a different group of soybean producers who share similar production concerns, such as weed management.
“We have a lot of tools for weed control from the conventional side that apply to organic soybean producers,” Cabello-Leiva said.
–Minnesota Soybean Research & Promotion Council
text:
MANKATO, Minn. — The Minnesota Soybean Research & Promotion Council (MSR&PC) has been on the road in the northern half of the state to begin 2026, interacting with farmers and sharing information on the latest checkoff research, including stops at the Soil Management Summit and DIRT Conference, MN Organics Conference and Small Grains Update Meetings.

For MSR&PC Director of Research Sergio Cabello Leiva, the northern Minnesota ramble was a return to his research roots.

“It’s a very exciting time of year because it’s an opportunity for us at Minnesota Soybean to deliver information to our audience of farmers and ag professionals all throughout the state,” said Cabello Leiva. “I love the northern part of the state as I spent several years working in North Dakota and northern Minnesota, so it’s good to be back.”

The Soil Management Summit and DIRT conference, a combined effort of the University of Minnesota and North Dakota State University, puts an emphasis on farmer experience and applied science on the topic of soil health and sustainability. The conference, which was held Jan. 14-15 in Fargo, N.D. on Jan. 14-15, featured presentations, Q&As with researchers, farmers and ag professionals, trade show and ample learning and networking opportunities.

“The Soil Management Summit is a great opportunity for farmers, ag professionals and scientists to get together and talk about sustainability and protecting our soils,” said Cabello Leiva, who joined MSR&PC in spring 2025. “The way I see things is that if we have a healthy soil, we have high organic matter; basically we are saving money for our future. We are giving more nutrients to our crops, more healthy crops, more healthy balance. It’s a win-win situation.”

As a sponsor of the event, MSR&PC hosted a table talk at the conference, providing a chance for producers and researchers to have an informal, roundtable discussion about research and agronomic practices.

“The presenter at the table doesn’t have a PowerPoint, maybe a small handout, but it’s meant to be informal, meant to stimulate discussion, and it’s meant for researchers and farmers to learn from one another,” said Dr. Angie Peltier, U of M Extension Educator who hosted the table talk on behalf of MRS&PC. “Everyone at the table has an equal voice and can share their own experiences. The learning that happens during those interactions is tremendous.”

Peltier spoke at her table talk about some of the latest checkoff=supported research projects and how that research can drive yield and long-term profitability for Minnesota farms.

“We chatted a lot about soybean cyst nematode and knowing that risk, because a lot of producers still have no idea that their field could be infested and that is our No. 1 yield impactor in soybean fields,” said Peltier. “We also discussed one of the newest pathogens found in the state called Red Crown Rot, so it’s important that farmers keep an eye out for that and other emerging threats and that we collaborate to come up with workable management practices to address those threats.”

In addition to the Soil Management Summit, MSR&PC also sponsored and participated in the MN Organic Conference Jan. 8-9 in St. Cloud, followed by Small Grains Update meetings throughout northwest Minnesota. The MN Organic Conference was unique in that it spearheaded conversations and interactions with a different group of soybean producers who share similar production concerns, such as weed management.

“We have a lot of tools for weed control from the conventional side that apply to organic soybean producers,” Cabello-Leiva said. “It’s a good partnership and there are a lot of mutual benefits for our food-grade soybean producers, of which we are developing new varieties for right here in the state with the University and Minnesota Soybean together.”

The Small Grains Update meetings made stops all throughout the Red River Valley, including Dilworth, Halstad, Crookston, Lancaster, Roseau and St. Hilaire. In a time where market prices are low and inputs are high, Cabella Leiva spoke to producers on how they can get the best bang for their buck through utilizing available research, applying only what farmers need and staying on top of agronomic issues that impact yield.

“A good variety, a good seed treatment, good fertility in our soils and just apply the absolute necessary to obtain the biggest yield and best quality,” he said. “There’s an opportunity to improve by just applying what we need. We have a lot of research about that, and we invite people to take a look at our research book for those solutions.”

Throughout the slate of conference and meetings, farmers had the opportunity to pick up MSR&PC’s latest research report, From Seed to Solutions. The publication can be viewed online here. Cabello Leiva and checkoff researchers will also be in attendance to visit with producers Jan. 20-21 at MN Ag Expo in Mankato.

–Minnesota Soybean Research & Promotion Council

title: DG Fuels town hall meeting provided project updates while answering local concerns
description:
Julie Bushell of Global Sustainability Developers, LLC (GSD) and DG Fuels CEO Mike Darcy were on site to also address any concerns from Phelps County residents.
The Phelps County Development Corporation (PCDC) hosted the town hall meeting at the Phelps County Ag Center on Wednesday, January 14.
Darcy made it clear that a SAF facility runs cleaner than a conventional petroleum refinery, while producing an environmentally friendly product.
Members of local public power districts were also in attendance.
He said it was exciting to know that local farmers would now have the opportunity to benefit from the project before the Phelps County SAF plant is complete.
text:
Holdrege, Neb. – For the second time since the proposed DG Fuels Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) facility was announced in August 2024, residents of Phelps County were invited to hear directly from those who are working closely on the project. Julie Bushell of Global Sustainability Developers, LLC (GSD) and DG Fuels CEO Mike Darcy were on site to also address any concerns from Phelps County residents. The Phelps County Development Corporation (PCDC) hosted the town hall meeting at the Phelps County Ag Center on Wednesday, January 14.

A lot of those concerns addressed the use of corn stover and how the facility may affect resources in the area. On more than one occasion, Darcy and Bushell assured the audience that great care is being taken to ensure the SAF facility would not cause many difficulties for Phelps County residents. Darcy made it clear that a SAF facility runs cleaner than a conventional petroleum refinery, while producing an environmentally friendly product.

Following the wave of disapproval from local residents regarding the initial plans to bring fresh water in by train, Bushell announced that an environmental study was being conducted on the state’s surface water sources and the Ogallala Aquifer. The study is expected to be completed and made available to the public by the end of March.

Members of local public power districts were also in attendance. Courtney Dentlinger of NPPD and Chad Waldo of Southern PPD assured residents that they were behind the project, noting that the facility would not be a drain on the area’s electrical resources.

Bushell confirmed that a location in Phelps County has been chosen but will not be made public out of respect to the landowner’s privacy.

PCDC executive director Jeff Hofaker recognized that while there a few things that still need to be worked on, he remains enthusiastic about the project. The news of the pellet facility was especially welcome to Hofaker. He said it was exciting to know that local farmers would now have the opportunity to benefit from the project before the Phelps County SAF plant is complete.

title: Radicle Growth Launches the Radicle Corn Challenge Sponsored by U.S. Corn Farmers to ...
description:
LINCOLN, Nebraska – Radicle Growth has announced the launch of The Radicle Corn Challenge sponsored by U.S. corn farmers, a global call for startups developing technologies that create new, durable demand for corn through innovative products, materials and value chains.
“The Radicle Corn Challenge represents a vital opportunity to uncover innovative, breakthrough solutions that benefit farmers and consumers alike.
For more information about The Radicle Corn Challenge Sponsored by U.S. corn Farmers and to apply, visit radicle.vc/radicle-corn-challenge.
About the Nebraska Corn Board: The Nebraska Corn Board is funded through a producer checkoff investment of one-cent-per-bushel on all corn marketed in the state and is managed by nine farmer directors.
The mission of the Nebraska Corn Board to increase the value and sustainability of Nebraska corn through promotion, market development and research.
text:
LINCOLN, Nebraska – Radicle Growth has announced the launch of The Radicle Corn Challenge sponsored by U.S. corn farmers, a global call for startups developing technologies that create new, durable demand for corn through innovative products, materials and value chains. The Challenge will invest a total of $1.75 million in selected companies and is supported by twelve leading U.S. corn grower organizations: Colorado Corn Promotion Council, Corn Marketing Program of Michigan, Illinois Corn Marketing Board, Iowa Corn Promotion Board, Kansas Corn Commission, Kentucky Corn Promotion Council, Missouri Corn Merchandising Council, National Corn Growers Association, Nebraska Corn Board, Ohio Corn Marketing Program, South Dakota Corn Utilization Council and Tennessee Corn Promotion Board.

The Radicle Corn Challenge is designed to support startups that are building new uses for corn by helping discover additional sources of demand across industrial, material, chemical and fuel applications. In addition to capital, selected companies will benefit from Radicle’s commercialization expertise, scientific and technical diligence, and connections across the corn and broader bioeconomy ecosystem.

“Corn has long been a foundational feedstock for food, feed and fuel,” said Kirk Haney, managing partner at Radicle Growth. “The next opportunity is expanding how corn is used across new products and markets. Through the Radicle Corn Challenge, we’re looking to support companies that can translate innovation into real-world demand.”

The Challenge seeks applications from startups and growth companies worldwide that are working on technologies converting corn and corn-derived streams, such as sugar (glucose), ethanol and other byproducts, into higher-value products. Areas of interest include bioplastics and materials, corn- and ethanol-derived chemicals, valorization of corn byproducts and emerging fuel pathways, including marine fuels and sustainable aviation fuel.

“Advances in chemistry, catalysis, and biological conversion are opening up new, practical pathways for corn-based products,” said Neal Gutterson, partner and chief technology officer at Radicle Growth. “What’s particularly compelling today is how many of these technologies are becoming technically and commercially viable at scale.”

Historically, corn growers have played an active role in building and growing new markets, including the early development of the ethanol industry. The Challenge explores how similar alignment between innovators, investors and growers can help scale the next generation of corn-based technologies.

“As corn production continues to expand, we must develop new and diverse uses for our crop beyond Nebraska’s renowned Golden Triangle, the interconnected system of corn, livestock and ethanol that powers our state’s economy and helps fuel the world,” said Brandon Hunnicutt, Nebraska Corn Board chair and farmer from Giltner, Nebraska. “The Radicle Corn Challenge represents a vital opportunity to uncover innovative, breakthrough solutions that benefit farmers and consumers alike. In 2025, we witnessed exciting advancements in corn utilization, and we look forward to supporting forward-thinking companies that will continue driving new demand for Nebraska and U.S. grown corn.”

Investment decisions will be made following a comprehensive due diligence process, with selected winners announced at the Bio Innovations North America conference on September 9, 2026, in Omaha, Nebraska.

For more information about The Radicle Corn Challenge Sponsored by U.S. corn Farmers and to apply, visit radicle.vc/radicle-corn-challenge.

About the Nebraska Corn Board:

The Nebraska Corn Board is funded through a producer checkoff investment of one-cent-per-bushel on all corn marketed in the state and is managed by nine farmer directors. The mission of the Nebraska Corn Board to increase the value and sustainability of Nebraska corn through promotion, market development and research.
